[warm] Twenty-three canvases sealed behind plaster, [excited], each one signed with your name from 1998 through 2001. [chuckle]

[trembling] Those paintings were supposed to be, [quietly], destroyed after my breakdown when I thought I'd, [bitter], never create anything meaningful again and couldn't bear to, [slowly], look at who I used to be.
Well, um, whoever sealed them in that wall, [empathetically], protected them perfectly, like they knew, [hopeful], someday you'd want them back, you know?
[anxious] My ex-partner must have hidden them instead of, [regretful], burning them like I begged, thinking maybe I'd, [whispering], heal enough to see them differently.
[curious] I mean, when I pulled away that drywall and saw, [carefully], all those colors exploding out, um, it felt like, [animated], discovering buried treasure, you know?

[crying while speaking] Um, I haven't painted with that kind of, [passionately], raw honesty in twenty years because, well, losing those pieces felt like losing, [exhausted], the best part of myself, you know?
[sincerely] The way light hits them through the gallery windows makes them, [delighted], glow like stained glass, and everyone who's seen them stops, [very quietly], completely mesmerized.
Um, I can't, you know.

[friendly] Well, I've been in construction thirty years, and, um, I've torn down, [proudly], countless walls, but this is the first time I've ever, [emotionally], given someone their life back. [sigh]
[relieved] These paintings capture who I was before fear made me, [hesitantly], careful, before I started painting what I thought would, [sad], sell instead of what burned inside me. [laugh]
[whispering loudly] Um, they're beautiful.
I mean, looking at them now feels like, [overwhelmed], meeting my younger self who still believed art could, um, change things.
[gentle] Well, um, maybe finding them again means you're ready to, [encouraging], paint with that same fearlessness, to trust that, [confidently], what you create matters, you know?

[tearful] Um, when I thought these were gone forever, I mean, I convinced myself that, [frustrated], mediocre work was all I had left, but seeing them now, [amazed], I remember who I really am, you know? [gasp]
[thoughtful] You know, um, sometimes we bury things not to destroy them but to, [wise], preserve them until we're strong enough to, well, [optimistic], carry their weight again.
[determined] Tomorrow's exhibition was supposed to showcase twenty years of, [disgusted], safe choices, but now I'm hanging these lost pieces, [courageously], exactly as they are.

The gallery owner mentioned you hadn't, [surprised], shown anything publicly in years, said you'd become, [sympathetic], almost reclusive about your work, avoiding any real, [concerned], exposure or critique.
[fierce] Well, um, these paintings deserve to breathe again, to, [liberated], remind me why I started, and maybe they'll speak to someone else who's, [vulnerable], forgotten their own fire, you know?
[moved] That's the thing about walls—they hide things but they also, [profound], preserve them for exactly the right moment. [long pause]
